content: Hi all. What is the relation between the Hopf subalgebras of a finite-dimensional Hopf algebra H, and the Hopf subalgebras of the dual Hopf algebra H^*? Is it as straightforward as "A is a Hopf subalgebra of H iff A^* is a Hopf subalgebra of H^*" ?
Well, we can just try and see

I guess that the definition of a Hopf subalgebra of a Hopf kkk-algebra (H,η,∇,ϵ,Δ,S)(H,\eta,\nabla,\epsilon,\Delta,S)(H,η,∇,ϵ,Δ,S) is a sub-kkk-vector space A⊆HA \subseteq HA⊆H such that:

  • if λ∈k\lambda \in kλ∈k, then η(λ)∈A\eta(\lambda) \in Aη(λ)∈A
  • if a1,a2∈Aa_1,a_2 \in Aa1​,a2​∈A, then ∇(a1⊗a2)∈A\nabla(a_1 \otimes a_2) \in A∇(a1​⊗a2​)∈A
  • if a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, then Δ(a)∈A⊗A\Delta(a) \in A \otimes AΔ(a)∈A⊗A
  • if a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, then S(a)∈AS(a) \in AS(a)∈A

Now for every Hopf algebra HHH, I obtain by duality these maps:

  • η∗:H∗→k∗\eta^*: H^* \rightarrow k^*η∗:H∗→k∗
  • Δ∗:(H⊗H)∗→H∗\Delta^*: (H \otimes H)^* \rightarrow H^*Δ∗:(H⊗H)∗→H∗
  • ϵ∗:k∗→H∗\epsilon^*: k^* \rightarrow H^*ϵ∗:k∗→H∗
  • ∇∗:H∗→(H⊗H)∗\nabla^*: H^* \rightarrow (H \otimes H)^*∇∗:H∗→(H⊗H)∗
  • S∗:H∗→H∗S^*:H^* \rightarrow H^*S∗:H∗→H∗

If HHH is finite-dimensional, I know by the compact closed structure of the category of finite-dimensional vector spaces, that we have this isomorphism of kkk-vector spaces:

  • (H⊗H)∗≅H∗⊗H∗(H \otimes H)^* \cong H^* \otimes H^*(H⊗H)∗≅H∗⊗H∗

Moreover, we also have:

  • k∗≅kk^* \cong kk∗≅k

Let's denote as below the maps that we obtain by combining the dual maps with these isomorphisms:

  • η∨:H∗→k\eta^\vee:H^* \rightarrow kη∨:H∗→k
  • ∇∨:H∗⊗H∗→H∗\nabla^\vee:H^* \otimes H^* \rightarrow H^*∇∨:H∗⊗H∗→H∗
  • ϵ∨:K→H∗\epsilon^\vee:K \rightarrow H^*ϵ∨:K→H∗
  • Δ∨:H∗→H∗⊗H∗\Delta^\vee:H^* \rightarrow H^* \otimes H^*Δ∨:H∗→H∗⊗H∗
  • S∨:H∗→H∗S^\vee:H^* \rightarrow H^*S∨:H∗→H∗
I guess that we call the dual of a finite-dimensional Hopf algebra HHH is (H∗,η∨,∇∨,ϵ∨,Δ∨,S∨)(H^*,\eta^\vee,\nabla^\vee,\epsilon^\vee,\Delta^\vee,S^\vee)(H∗,η∨,∇∨,ϵ∨,Δ∨,S∨)
-> If AAA is a Hopf sub-algebra of the finite-dimensional Hopf algebra HHH, then is A∗A^*A∗ a Hopf subalgebra of H∗H^*H∗?
I guess that you can't go without using the sacrilegious isomorphisms A≅A∗A \cong A^*A≅A∗ and H≅H∗H \cong H^*H≅H∗ ie. choosing basis.
I don't see how you would see A∗A^*A∗ as a subspace of H∗H^*H∗ without that
Let's choose a basis (e1,...,en)(e_1,...,e_n)(e1​,...,en​) of AAA and complete it into a basis (e1,...,en+p)(e_1,...,e_{n+p})(e1​,...,en+p​) of HHH.
Then we have the dual basis (e1∗,...,en+p∗)(e_1^*,...,e_{n+p}^*)(e1∗​,...,en+p∗​) of H∗H^*H∗. For every 1≤k≤n1 \le k \le n1≤k≤n, write ei♯=ei∗∣Ae_i^\sharp = e_i^*|_{A}ei♯​=ei∗​∣A​
(e1♯,...,en♯)(e_1^\sharp,...,e_n^\sharp)(e1♯​,...,en♯​) is a basis of A∗A^*A∗. Indeed it's a free family of n=dim(A∗)n=dim(A^*)n=dim(A∗) vectors:

ei♯(ej)=ei∗(ej)=δi,je_i^\sharp(e_j)=e_i^*(e_j)=\delta_{i,j}ei♯​(ej​)=ei∗​(ej​)=δi,j​ and thus ∑λiei♯=0⇒∀1≤j≤n,(∑λiei♯)(ej)=λj=0\sum \lambda_i e_i^\sharp = 0 \Rightarrow \forall 1 \le j \le n, (\sum \lambda_i e_i^\sharp)(e_j) = \lambda_j = 0∑λi​ei♯​=0⇒∀1≤j≤n,(∑λi​ei♯​)(ej​)=λj​=0
Thus, we have an isomorphism ∑λiei♯↦∑λiei∗\sum \lambda_i e_i^\sharp \mapsto \sum \lambda_i e_i^*∑λi​ei♯​↦∑λi​ei∗​ from A∗A^*A∗ to Span(e1∗,...,en∗)Span(e_1^*,...,e_n^*)Span(e1∗​,...,en∗​)
With this identification, you can see A∗A^*A∗ as a subspace of H∗H^*H∗
And you can ask whether A∗A^*A∗, ie. Span(e1∗,...,en∗)Span(e_1^*,...,e_n^*)Span(e1∗​,...,en∗​) is not only a sub-vector space of H∗H^*H∗ but moreover a Hopf sub-algebra of H∗H^*H∗.
With these coordinates, it's going to be a hassle...

By definition, we want to know whether:

  • if λ∈k\lambda \in kλ∈k, then η∨(λ)∈A∗\eta^\vee(\lambda) \in A^*η∨(λ)∈A∗
  • if b1,b2∈A∗b_1,b_2 \in A^*b1​,b2​∈A∗, then ∇∨(b1⊗b2)∈A∗\nabla^\vee(b_1 \otimes b_2) \in A^*∇∨(b1​⊗b2​)∈A∗
  • if b∈A∗b \in A^*b∈A∗, then Δ∨(b)∈A∗⊗A∗\Delta^\vee(b) \in A^* \otimes A^*Δ∨(b)∈A∗⊗A∗
  • if b∈A∗b \in A^*b∈A∗, then S∨(b)∈A∗S^\vee(b) \in A^*S∨(b)∈A∗
    where A∗A^*A∗ must be understood as Span(e1∗,...,en∗)Span(e_1^*,...,e_n^*)Span(e1∗​,...,en∗​)
Pff, I think there is probably a better approach that this coordinate nightmare...

Alonso Perez-Lona said:

What is the relation between the Hopf subalgebras of a finite-dimensional Hopf algebra H, and the Hopf subalgebras of the dual Hopf algebra H^*? Is it as straightforward as "A is a Hopf subalgebra of H iff A^* is a Hopf subalgebra of H^*" ?

Subalgebras of a finite-dimensional Hopf algebra correspond to quotient algebras of its dual.
How do you know this?

For starters, taking duals is a contravariant functor sending inclusions i:V↪Wi: V \hookrightarrow Wi:V↪W to quotient maps i∗:W∗→V∗i^\ast: W^\ast \to V^\asti∗:W∗→V∗, algebras to coalgebras and coalgebras to algebras.
What are you quotienting by in your quotient map?
The subspace of W∗W^\astW∗ consisting of functionals that vanish on all of im(V)⊆Wim(V) \subseteq Wim(V)⊆W.
Ok
That was the main point I think ahah. I didn't know that. The rest doesn't look too difficult.
I will definitely remember that
Could you give more details on this point?

You say that if i:V→Wi:V \rightarrow Wi:V→W is an (injective?) linear map between two (finite-dimensional?) vector spaces and E={ϕ∈W∗ s.t. ∀v∈V ϕ(i(v))=0}E=\{\phi \in W^*~s.t.~\forall v \in V~\phi(i(v)) = 0\}E={ϕ∈W∗ s.t. ∀v∈V ϕ(i(v))=0}, then V∗≅W∗/EV^{*} \cong W^*/EV∗≅W∗/E
What's the isomorphism exactly?
Oh no I see
No, I don't

Assuming i:V→Wi: V \to Wi:V→W is an injective map between finite-dimensional vector spaces, then we get i∗ ⁣:W∗→V∗i^\ast \colon W^\ast \to V^\asti∗:W∗→V∗ in the usual way:

i∗(f)(v)=f(i(v)) i^\ast(f) (v) = f(i(v)) i∗(f)(v)=f(i(v))

for all f∈W∗f \in W^\astf∈W∗. My claim (a well-known fact) is that i∗i^\asti∗ is surjective, with kernel equal to

E={f∈W∗ such that  ∀v∈V f(i(v))=0}E=\{f \in W^*\textrm{ such that }~\forall v \in V~f(i(v)) = 0\}E={f∈W∗ such that  ∀v∈V f(i(v))=0},
It then follows that i∗i^\asti∗ gives an isomorphism from W∗/EW^\ast/EW∗/E to V∗V^\astV∗.

(Whenever you have a surjective linear map between vector spaces F:A→BF: A \to BF:A→B it gives an isomorphism F′:A/ker(F)→BF^\prime: A/\mathrm{ker}(F) \to BF′:A/ker(F)→B defined by F′([a])=F(a)F^\prime([a]) = F(a)F′([a])=F(a).)
I just made a few claims here; if there's one that's hard to check let me know.
Makes sense, thanks everyone.

John Baez said:

Assuming i:V→Wi: V \to Wi:V→W is an injective map between finite-dimensional vector spaces, then we get i∗ ⁣:W∗→V∗i^\ast \colon W^\ast \to V^\asti∗:W∗→V∗ in the usual way:

i∗(f)(v)=f(i(v)) i^\ast(f) (v) = f(i(v)) i∗(f)(v)=f(i(v))

for all f∈W∗f \in W^\astf∈W∗. My claim (a well-known fact) is that i∗i^\asti∗ is surjective...

Intuitively, this is interesting - it's like the ways in which VVV relates to the underlying field are all "contained inside" of the ways in which the larger vector space WWW relates to the underlying field. In symbols, I think the surjectivity of i∗i^\asti∗ means that for any g:V→Kg: V \to Kg:V→K, where KKK is the field our vector spaces are defined over (and viewed as a 1D vector space), then we can find a f:W→Kf: W \to Kf:W→K so that f∘i=gf \circ i = gf∘i=g.

I wonder if a related more general statement is true (subject to some conditions to be determined): Let i:V→Wi: V \to Wi:V→W be a representative of a subobject in some category, where we view subobjects as an isomorphism class of monomorphisms. So, i:V→Wi: V \to Wi:V→W is a monomorphism. Then, let g:V→Kg: V \to Kg:V→K be some morphism from VVV to another object KKK. I wonder if we can always find a f:W→Kf: W \to Kf:W→K so that ggg factors through WWW using fff. That is, so that g=f∘ig = f \circ ig=f∘i.

I don't know what the minimum requirements are for this to be true. But let us consider the case where W=V∐V′W = V \coprod V'W=V∐V′ for some object V′V'V′. In this case, let i:V→V∐V′i: V \to V \coprod V'i:V→V∐V′ and i′:V′→V∐V′i': V' \to V \coprod V'i′:V′→V∐V′ be the two coprojection morphisms associated with V∐V′V \coprod V'V∐V′. Then let g:V→Kg: V \to Kg:V→K be the morphism we wish to factor through WWW. Let g′:V′→Kg': V' \to Kg′:V′→K be any morphism from V′V'V′ to KKK. Then, by the universal property of coproducts, there is a unique f:V∐V′→Kf: V \coprod V' \to Kf:V∐V′→K so that f∘i=gf \circ i = gf∘i=g and f∘i′=g′f \circ i' = g'f∘i′=g′.

So, in this case, there is always a way to factor f:V→Kf: V \to Kf:V→K through a g:W→Kg: W \to Kg:W→K. Here are the two assumptions we made to achieve this, in addition to assuming that i:V→Wi: V \to Wi:V→W is a monomorphism:

  • WWW is a coproduct of VVV and some object V′V'V′, and i:V→Wi: V \to Wi:V→W is one of the coprojections
  • there is at least one morphism from V′V'V′ to KKK
Incidentally, what is the precise relation between Rep(H) and Rep(H^*) for H a finite-dimensional Hopf algebra? Can Rep(H^* ) be realized as some sort of Bimodule category of Rep(H)?

I don't know a simple relation between Rep(H) and Rep(H*). Maybe there is one, but this is all I know:

If we start with, not just the category Rep(H) but also the forgetful functor

F: Rep(H) →\to→ Vect

we can recover H itself as the Hopf algebra of natural transformations from F to itself. This is called Tannaka duality. We can then form H* and then form Rep(H*) and its forgetful functor

G: Rep(H*) →\to→ Vect

But it would be nice to go from F: Rep(H) →\to→ Vect to G: Rep(H*) →\to→ Vect more directly!
